awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Converging Genomics, Phenomics, and Environments Using Interpretable Machine Learning Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Mitigating the effects of climate change on public health and conservation calls for a better understanding of the dynamic interplay between biological processes and environmental effects. The state-of-the-art, which has led to many important discoveries, utilizes numerical or statistical models for making predictions or performing in silico experimentation, but these techniques struggle to capture the nonlinear response of natural systems. Machine learning (ML) methods are better able to cope with nonlinearity and have been used successfully in biological applications, but several barriers still exist, including the opaque nature of the algorithm output and the absence of ML-ready data. This project seeks to significantly advance technologies in ML and create a new interdisciplinary field, computational ecogenomics. This will be accomplished by designing ML techniques for encoding heterogeneous genomic and environmental data and mapping them to multi-level phenotypic traits, reducing the amount of necessary training data, and then developing interactive visualizations to better interpret ML models and their outputs.  These advances will responsibly and transparently inform policy to maximize resources during this crucial window for planetary health, while revealing underlying biological mechanisms of response to stress and evolutionary pressure.

The long-term vision for this project is to develop predictive analytics for organismal response to environmental perturbations using innovative data science approaches and change the way scientists think about gene expression and the environment. The goal for this two-year award is to develop a proof-of-concept for an institute focused on predicting emergent properties of complex systems; an institute that would itself foster the development of many new sub-disciplines.  The core of this activity is developing a machine learning framework capable of predicting phenotypes based on multi-scale data about genes and environments.  Available data, ranging from simple vectors to complex images to sequences, will be ingested into this framework by applying proven semantic data integration tools and algorithmic data transformation methods.  The central hypothesis of this research is that deep learning algorithms and biological knowledge graphs will predict phenotypes more accurately across more taxa and more ecosystems than do current numerical and traditional statistical modeling methods.  The rationale for this project is that a timely investment in data science will push through a bottleneck in life science, accelerating discovery of gene-phenotype-environment relationships, and catalyzing a new computational discipline to uncover the complex "rules of life."

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity, and is jointly supported by the HDR and the Division of Biological Infrastructure within the NSF Directorate of Directorate for Biological Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The future of agricultural research lies in our ability to utilize the latest technology and modern approaches to understanding the complex relationship between crop plant genotypes, the environment and how those determine plant phenotypes. The most important traits of interest in agricultural plant breeding, such as growth, plant height, and yield, are generally determined by suites of genes rather than a single gene and are influenced by environmental factors.  This complicates the process of identifying the causal factors and has led to developing new approaches. Plant or animal breeding projects carried out by crop production or livestock companies strive to discover the complex suite of genes behind desired phenotypes. The GenoPhenoEnvo (GPE) project (https://genophenoenvo.github.io/) contributed to the long-term scientific goal of fully defining the processes that translate an organism?s genetic endowment into observable traits and ecosystem functions. This is a very difficult task because of the complexity of these processes, their interactions, and the incredibly heterogeneous nature of the data needed to increase understanding. The GPE project advanced the field by creating workflows for 1) standardizing, integrating, and visualizing data, 2) performing feature extraction on genomic data, and 3) developing knowledge models for gene regulatory networks. A key finding of our work was the realization that functional gene annotations need to include information about environmental context, especially for the more complex phenotypes. Environmental influences may affect regulatory genes in ways that do not correspond to the evolutionary orthologous relationships that are typically exploited in genomic knowledge bases. Currently, gene function annotations do not include this information and genomic knowledge bases are not designed to model these relationships. Defining the underlying data and knowledge models and processes for data transformation are essential for building algorithms that can predict phenotype using data about genes and environments. This work demonstrated the need for updated models and proposed a suite of new data and relationships to include to better understand the modeling of gene and environmental regulation of phenotype.

The products of GPE include a 1) plant genetic knowledge graph, 2) additions to the Planteome database and reference ontologies (https://planteome.org/) , including the Plant Trait Ontology, 3) analytical and data transformation workflows, and 4) ecological function prediction models. The Planteome KG was populated with data from the EMBL-EBI Expression Atlas and was used to connect homology-based gene annotations to gene expression and function data in two model plant species (Thessen et al., 2023). The ecological function prediction models focused on phenology forecasting using images from the NEON PhenoCam. These models were submitted to the EFI RCN NEON forecasting challenge and are freely available for reuse.

The code, models, and tools created by GPE are freely available in CyVerse and on GitHub. In addition, the collaborative relationships built during this project will forge additional transdisciplinary research in the future around the development of large language models (LLM) and knowledge graphs for phenotype prediction. 

The broader impacts of this work include increasing public engagement with science and technology through the interaction with the USA National Phenology Network (NPN), which consists of thousands of volunteer observers. An improved ability to predict phenotypes in cultivated plants will improve the efficiency of breeding programs and an increase competitiveness in the agri-food industry.  Tools and software developed by the GPE project are freely available under FAIR data use principles. These tools can be extended for adoption beyond the biological domain applications. 



Reference: Thessen AE, Cooper L, Swetnam TL, Hegde H, Reese J, Elser J and Jaiswal P (2023) Using knowledge graphs to infer gene expression in plants. Front. Artif. Intell. 6:1201002. doi: 10.3389/frai.2023.1201002
